title.narrative: Strategic Partnership CHD 2019-2022

description.narrative: A multi-annual strategic partnership between the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD) which enables HD to respond rapidly and appropriately to developing political and violent crises and opportunities. The partnership provides the MFA with valued activities in mediation around the world and in regions of priority interest to the Netherlands while opening up networks more readily available to an independent, private actor.

HD Strategy 2019-2023
3.1 Number of dialogue processes to promote constructive conflict management and local peace processes

description.narrative: NL MFA Security and Rule of Law results framework - Process indicator

title.narrative: 2.1.1 % coverage by HD projects and assessments of those countries affected by highly violent conflicts (HD indicator)

description.narrative: Percentage of coverage is based on HD's engagement in countries affected by highly violent conflicts, as listed by the Conflict Barometer published by the Heidelberg Institute. HD also engages in conflicts not on this list, either because they have escalated, are classified as frozen or protracted conflicts, or because HD engages in preventive action.

comment.narrative: In 2019, HD covered 80% of all countries affected by violent conflict
In 2021, HD covered about 81% of countries affected by highly violent political conflicts.

title.narrative: 3.1.1 Support to strengthen third-party mediation in peace processes aimed at reaching inclusive peace agreements

description.narrative: NL MFA Security and Rule of Law results framework - output

title.narrative: 3.2 No. of dialogue processes to promote constructive conflict management and local peace processes (ARC optional indicator)

comment.narrative: At the end of 2019, HD was implementing at least 45 mediation and dialogue projects across the globe. Although some are multi-track, each of these projects are here counted as one dialogue process.
In 2021, HD maintained approximately 40 projects in over 40 countries.
At the end of 2020, HD was implementing at least 50 mediation and dialogue projects across the globe. Although some are multi-track, each of these projects are here counted as one dialogue process.

title.narrative: 3.1.1 Support to strengthen third-party mediation in peace processes aimed at reaching inclusive peace agreements

description.narrative: NL MFA Security and Rule of Law results framework - output

title.narrative: 3.1 No. and % of conflicts that are addressed and resolved by community structures by the programme (ARC indicator) 1.1.1 Number of local conflicts mediated or supported (HD indicator)

comment.narrative: 82 local level agreements
161 local level agreements

In 2020, HD successfully mediated or supported the resolution of at least 451 local conflicts, most of these in Francophone Africa. HD facilitated and supported 6 local peace agreements and the resolution of 435 local agro-pastoral conflicts across Togo and the Sahel region. In the Philippines, HD’s subsidiary in Sulu mediated 17 cases of clan conflict, helping the parties involved reach a formal settlement in 8 of them, and two ceasefires.
400 local-level agreements

In the Sahel, HD mediated conflicts at the local level across Mali, Niger, Burkina Faso, Mauritania, Chad and Central African Republic. This work led to the resolution of 464 agro-pastoral conflicts, and 3 local agreements for the peaceful exploitation of disputed natural resources in Chad and Mali. HD’s network of religious mediators in Mali prevented or resolved 19 conflicts. In CAR, HD’s three cross-border networks on the border with Cameroon resolved 109 agro-pastoral conflicts. In the Philippines, HD’s subsidiary in Sulu mediated 26 cases of clan conflict between January and December 2021. Following this mediation, a formal settlement was reached in five conflicts.

title.narrative: 3.2.3 Policy influencing on aspects of political governance and state building

description.narrative: NL MFA Security and Rule of Law results framework - output

title.narrative: No. of dialogue processes to strengthen the political/public debate (No of HD dialogue initiatives that include a public dialogue component)

comment.narrative: HD is not a public advocacy organisation, but much of HD’s work tries to contribute and strengthen the political debate or discreetly influence policy or peace process design in local, national and sometimes regional contexts the scenes. Sometimes this includes a specific focus on strengthening the public debate, such as HD’s work on preventing COVID-19 related misinformation, but will more often be in the form of discreet advisory services to conflict parties, facilitating dialogue with key stakeholders and experts, and sometimes as mediators between conflict parties. In 2021, the number of HD projects that include a public dialogue component was 26 (14 in Africa, 2 in Eurasia, 3 in Middle East and North Africa, and 6 in Asia, plus 1 global/cross-cutting project).
In 2019, the number of HD projects that include a public dialogue component was 27 (14 in Africa, 1 in Eurasia, 3 in Middle East and North Africa, and 9 in Asia).
In 2020, the number of HD projects that include a public dialogue component was 25 (12 in Africa, 1 in Eurasia, 3 in Middle East and North Africa, and 9 in Asia).

title.narrative: 3.1 Peace processes: reaching and sustaining peace through inclusive peace agreements, conflict resolution and peacebuilding initiatives

description.narrative: NL MFA Security and Rule of Law results framework: Medium-term outcome

title.narrative: 1.2 Achievement of intermediate results (HD indicator)

description.narrative: Number of confidence-building measures, rapprochement of conflict actors, joint declarations or commitments, new channels of communication, mandates to mediate or facilitate, or first contact with conflict actors established.

comment.narrative: HD facilitated various intermediate results 2020, including: 7 interim declarations or statements of commitment to peace processes; 3 rapprochements and trust–building between conflict parties; 6 new channels of communication between conflict and third parties; 1 new mandate to support mediation.
For 2019 at least: 1 ceasefire, 1 new contact with conflict parties, 1 new mandate provided to HD, 1 unilateral declarations / commitment to peace processes

In 2019, HD facilitated at least: 4 instances of rapprochements and confidence-building between conflict parties; 1 agreement on a road map for negotiations; 4 new channels of communication between conflict and third parties; 3 first contacts between conflict parties; and 1 official mandate received by HD from conflict parties to support a peace process. Indicator is annual - figure is aggregate to date.
At least: 1 ceasefire 1 new contact with conflict parties 1 mandate provided to HD 1 declaration / commitment to peace processes

title.narrative: 3.1 Peace processes: reaching and sustaining peace through inclusive peace agreements, conflict resolution and peacebuilding initiatives

description.narrative: NL MFA Security and Rule of Law results framework: Medium-term outcome

title.narrative: 1.1 Achievement of final outcomes (HD indicator)

description.narrative: Number of peace and conflict management settlements, violence reduction measures (such as ceasefires) and humanitarian access agreements (per year)

comment.narrative: In 2019, HD projects have generated at least 27 significant interim and final peacemaking results. These include 8 peace and conflict management agreements and 6 cases of reduction or prevention of violence.

In 2020, HD projects have generated at least 27 significant final and interim peacemaking results. These include: 4 peace and conflict management agreements; 6 cases of reduction or prevention of violence, of which 3 ceasefires

In 2021, HD projects generated at least 28 significant final peacemaking results at the regional, national and local levels. These include 16 peace and conflict management agreements, and 12 agreements on violence reduction or humanitarian access, of which 8 at the national level
